items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Thursday, October 12.

title.children: NT leader says alternatives to Voice being prepped, Indigenous man turned away from polls over Yes shirt

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jake Evans Independent senator Lidia Thorpe, who has become a figurehead for progressive opponents of the Voice to Parliament, says the body should be enshrined in law even if the referendum fails. Senator Thorpe told ABC Radio National Breakfast that the prime minister's comments on the weekend he would abandon the Voice proposal if Australians vote it down was "weak". "It's a weak response, it's like, 'I throw my bat and run away, I don't want to play no more,' attitude," she said. The independent senator said she was opposed to the Voice being used as "window dressing" for Indigenous recognition in the constitution, which she views as insufficient to address Australia's colonial history. But Senator Thorpe said there should still be a Voice to Parliament, saying she would support legislation if it was not tied to the constitution.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lidia Thorpe says Voice should still be legislated if referendum fails

featuredLink.title: Lidia Thorpe, a No campaigner against the Voice, says Voice should be legislated if referendum fails

children.content: Lidia Thorpe says the nation needs a Voice to Parliament, though she is campaigning against the referendum proposal.
(ABC News: Luke Stephenson)
Reporting by Jake Evans
Independent senator
Lidia Thorpe
, who has become a figurehead for progressive opponents of the Voice to Parliament, says the body should be enshrined in law even if the referendum fails.
Senator Thorpe told ABC Radio National Breakfast that the prime minister's comments on the weekend he would abandon the Voice proposal if Australians vote it down was "weak".
"It's a weak response, it's like, 'I throw my bat and run away, I don't want to play no more,' attitude," she said.

The independent senator said she was opposed to the Voice being used as "window dressing" for Indigenous recognition in the constitution, which she views as insufficient to address Australia's colonial history.
But Senator Thorpe said there should still be a Voice to Parliament, saying she would support legislation if it was not tied to the constitution.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lucas Forbes Sebastian and Ella McCorry are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts. The eighteen-year-old Wiradjuri twins have been frustrated by misinformation about the Voice to Parliament referendum on TikTok and Facebook. They're part of their school's student representative council, which has been running Q & A sessions with younger students about the Voice. The council has also written to the parents of year 12 students, urging them to seek reliable information. Read more about Sebastian and Ella's work below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wiradjuri high schoolers fighting Voice misinformation

featuredLink.title: These twin high-schoolers say misinformation on the Voice is rampant among teens, so they're trying to fix that

children.content: The twins say some of their peers have been falsely told the Voice will raise rents.
(ABC Riverina: Lucas Forbes)
Reporting by Lucas Forbes
Sebastian and Ella McCorry
are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts.
The eighteen-year-old Wiradjuri twins have been frustrated by misinformation about the Voice to Parliament referendum on TikTok and Facebook.
They're part of their school's student representative council, which has been running Q
A sessions with younger students about the Voice. The council has also written to the parents of year 12 students, urging them to seek reliable information.
Read more about Sebastian and Ella's work below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader, Lia Finocchiaro, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a No vote will prevail in the territory. Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the Country Liberals, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government". "A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said. "Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities." At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs, Chief Minister Natasha Fyles criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NT opposition leader says alternatives to Voice being prepared

children.content: NT opposition leader Lia Finocchiaro is spruiking alternatives to the Voice.
(ABC News: Michael Franchi)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader,
Lia Finocchiaro
, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a
No vote will prevail in the territory
Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the
Country Liberals
, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government".
"A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said.
"Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities."
At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs,
Chief Minister Natasha Fyles
criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Pocock raised the matter of PwC's response to the internal review of PwC's governance and culture, by former Telstra chief executive Ziggy Switkowski, which had been commissioned by PwC. Pocock says PwC's response to the report has been woeful. She says PwC is just trying to skip the responsibility and accountability phase, and go straight to the future. She says PwC still isn't sharing information about who exactly it shared confidential tax information with, and it's still trying to pretend as though it can fix its culture and business practices with self-regulation. "You're assuming that you continue to govern yourself far from the prying eyes of ASIC," Senator Pocock said. "You've got self-regulatory actions that you're voluntary committing, you're committing to three non-executive independent directors, planning to publish audit statements applying the ASIC corporate governance principles, which are statements of intention and hope," she said. " They're motherhood statements about how good governance should look like. "But isn't it the case that as things stand, there are no regulatory consequences if you don't do any of these things? "They do not have teeth, and they do not constitute a significant shift in your regulatory framework. "You are offering self-regulation, which we as a Senate and the Australian public no longer trust you to apply. " You have lost social licence to self-regulate and the self-regulations you offer are completely inadequate to the challenges and the disaster that you present to the Australian people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'You have lost social licence to self-regulate'

featuredLink.title: A scathing review into PwC's culture unearths a 'whatever it takes' attitude that resulted in 'integrity failures'

children.content: Senator Pocock raised the matter of PwC's response to the internal review of PwC's governance and culture, by former Telstra chief executive Ziggy Switkowski,
which had been commissioned by PwC.
Pocock says PwC's response to the report has been woeful.
She says PwC is just trying to skip the responsibility and accountability phase, and go straight to the future.

She says PwC still isn't sharing information about who exactly it shared confidential tax information with, and it's still trying to pretend as though it can fix its culture and business practices with self-regulation.
"You're assuming that you continue to govern yourself far from the prying eyes of ASIC," Senator Pocock said.

"You've got self-regulatory actions that you're voluntary committing, you're committing to three non-executive independent directors, planning to publish audit statements applying the ASIC corporate governance principles, which are statements of intention and hope," she said.
They're motherhood statements
about how good governance should look like.
"But isn't it the case that as things stand, there are no regulatory consequences if you don't do any of these things?
"They do not have teeth, and they do not constitute a significant shift in your regulatory framework.
"You are offering self-regulation, which we as a Senate and the Australian public no longer trust you to apply.
You have lost social licence to self-regulate
and the self-regulations you offer are completely inadequate to the challenges and the disaster that you present to the Australian people.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC executives are up. Kevin Burrowes, PwC chief executive officer, has begun his evidence by reading from an opening statement. He's talked about the thousands of people PwC has employed over the decades, and the people it is proud to have trained. However, he says in January this year, the Tax Practitioners Board investigation into PwC revealed behaviour "we are not proud of". "What happened is totally unacceptable," he said. "We cannot apologise strongly enough for breaching the trust placed in us, and we accept the justifiable questions this raised about our trustworthiness and integrity, just as we commit to do better in the future," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC evidence begins

children.content: PwC executives are up.
Kevin Burrowes, PwC chief executive officer
, has begun his evidence by reading from an opening statement.
He's talked about the thousands of people PwC has employed over the decades, and the people it is proud to have trained.
However, he says in January this year, the
Tax Practitioners Board
investigation into PwC revealed behaviour "we are not proud of".
"What happened is totally unacceptable," he said.

"We cannot apologise strongly enough for breaching the trust placed in us, and we accept the justifiable questions this raised about our trustworthiness and integrity, just as we commit to do better in the future," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of Australia’s biggest coal miners is facing an investor backlash over its plans to buy two massive mines from BHP. London-based hedge fund Bell Rock Capital Management this morning has launched a campaign to thwart Whitehaven Coal from purchasing the two Queensland operations for a reputed $US5 billion. It will attempt to mobilise shareholders to protest the purchase by voting against the executive pay deals up before the Whitehaven annual meeting in a fortnight. BHP has been steadily reducing its coal exposure with a view to a complete exit and in recent months has been in negotiations with Whitehaven to purchase the Daunia and Blackwater mines in central Queensland. Both mines are jointly owned by BHP and Mitsubishi and have been on the market since February. The London-based investor has kicked off the campaign this morning with letters to all Whitehaven shareholders and an advertising blitz in major newspapers. Bell Rock, which owns close to 5 per cent of Whitehaven, is incensed that a key hurdle for executive bonuses has been removed from this year’s AGM agenda which it claims will encourage Whitehaven executives to pursue growth via acquisitions at the expense of shareholder returns. The proposed mine purchases are likely to cost Whitehaven almost as much as the company is worth and will need to be funded by a massive increase in debt. While the Daunia mine produces metallurgical coal for steelmaking, a large portion of Blackwater’s output is thermal coal, the demand for which is declining as efforts to battle climate change escalate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bell Rock Capital Management launches campaign to thwart Whitehaven Coal purchasing two mines

children.content: One of Australia’s biggest coal miners is facing an investor backlash over its
plans to buy two massive mines from BHP
London-based hedge fund
Bell Rock Capital Management
this morning has launched a campaign to thwart
Whitehaven Coal
from purchasing the two Queensland operations for a reputed $US5 billion.
It will attempt to mobilise shareholders to protest the purchase by voting against the executive pay deals up before the Whitehaven annual meeting in a fortnight.
BHP has been steadily reducing its coal exposure with a view to a complete exit and in recent months has been in negotiations with Whitehaven to purchase the
Daunia
and
Blackwater mines
in
central Queensland
. Both mines are jointly owned by
BHP
and
Mitsubishi
and have been on the market since February.
The London-based investor has kicked off the campaign this morning with letters to all Whitehaven shareholders and an advertising blitz in major newspapers.
Bell Rock, which owns close to 5 per cent of Whitehaven, is incensed that a key hurdle for executive bonuses has been removed from this year’s AGM agenda
which it claims will encourage Whitehaven executives to pursue growth via acquisitions at the expense of shareholder returns.
The proposed mine purchases are likely to cost Whitehaven almost as much as the company is worth and will need to be funded by a massive increase in debt.

While the Daunia mine produces metallurgical coal for steelmaking, a large portion of Blackwater’s output is thermal coal, the demand for which is declining as efforts to battle climate change escalate.
